abstract.p: Elliott R Barkan letter on April 16 review of book Taboo

block.p: In his review of Jon Entine's ''Taboo'' (April 16), Jim Holt enumerated three ''caveats'' as to why one must be careful about genetic conclusions concerning blacks in sports. Yet there is a fourth, major one that he neglects and that strongly undermines any argument, at least one concerning African-Americans.

In his review of Jon Entine's ''Taboo'' (April 16), Jim Holt enumerated three ''caveats'' as to why one must be careful about genetic conclusions concerning blacks in sports. Yet there is a fourth, major one that he neglects and that strongly undermines any argument, at least one concerning African-Americans.

The fact that there has been so much racial intermixing in America, with well over three-fourths of African-Americans having mixed-blood ancestry, makes any argument about the genetic connection between sports and their race specious. If most of these particular athletes are indeed racially mixed, how can one with certainty associate only their ''black genes'' with their athletic achievements and omit any reference to their ''white genes''?
Elliott R. Barkan San Bernardino, Calif.
